labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Agent browsing on behalf of a user action?
issues.author: mprorock
issues.body: @martinthomson do you see this as a mechanism to indicate whether an agent can access the data on behalf of a user when directed by a user to do so?

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
Are you talking about a typical user agent (i.e., a browser) or some new sort of agentic AI?  I don't think that applies here in either case, and so the agent would just be able to access the content.  But, if you are talking about the latter exclusively, which is AI and it is using the data, it's not entirely clear from what the draft includes.  Other similar systems separate out training and inference, where I chose not to, so this does create some ambiguity.

Clarifying that is a good idea, but I don't know which way this needs to point.  There's a lot riding on "when directed by a user" in your question.  That might mean that content is "used" by the person or it could be "used" by the agent, with the line between the two being pretty unclear.

issues.title: Consideration for a "maybe" rather than just yes/no prefs
issues.author: mprorock
issues.body:
@martinthomson would a value of "l" for "subject to license" make sense for a value?
This is more nuanced than just saying: no, it is basically a yes, but you must conform to certain rules that could be specified as a url contained in a "License" or "Content-License" header/section

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
I see where you are going, but I don't see this as materially different than 'n'.  It is always possible to include licensing information that can override preferences.  In most cases, a URL won't help an automated processor decide whether it can use content, because licenses are often just a reference to a legal document.  Some URLs might reference structured content (or reference a document containing structured content) that an automaton can use.  Where URLs are effectively identifiers and the automaton is able to know that it complies with a license, that is maybe a case for this.

In all of these case, these decisions can be made without a specific signal here.  There are existing mechanisms for signaling licensing terms in the form of a URL.  Unfortunately, there are an awful lot of them, but these preferences would not override any established licensing terms, they would only apply where those terms either allowed it, where the automaton is unable to determine that it is compliant with terms, or where there are no terms.

issues.title: Search?
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: The [openfuture report](https://openfuture.eu/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/250307_Vocabulary_for_opting_out_of_AI_training_and_other_forms_of_TDM.pdf) suggests that search might be best left out.  Their argument seems to reduce to "it would be too hard" combined with "that system isn't broken".  Both reasonable arguments.

issues.title: Including inference
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
This draft takes the position that this is about *use*.  That follows the "blurry JPEG of the internet" view where the training is only a means to an end, that being inference.  In that view, if there is anything that someone might seek to avoid, that would not be the acquisition of information, but its ultimate use.  That is, an artist might be less concerned about something looking at a painting than having that painting -- or aspects of it -- copied.

In contrast, the [openfuture report](https://openfuture.eu/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/250307_Vocabulary_for_opting_out_of_AI_training_and_other_forms_of_TDM.pdf) takes the opposing view: that use in inference is distinct from training.  The report acknowledges that there might be a desire to constrain things like <acronym title="Retrieval Augmented Generation">RAG</acronym> and that it might be necessary to expand the scope to include inference.  The obvious question there is whether the definition of existing categories can be expanded, or whether new categories would be needed.

issues.title: Invert determination algorithm
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
This could be simpler:
for each label you care about, check the value; if YES, keep going, if NO, return DENIED, if UNKNOWN, recurse to the more specific label; if still UNKNOWN, pick a value according to local preference; when the loop ends without returning DENIED, return ALLOWED

issues.title: Applicability of robots.txt over time
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
A few things to consider:

Does the expression that is carried in robots.txt attach to content (a) while the robots.txt is fresh (in the caching sense) or (b) during the industry-standard 24 hours that crawlers are expected to follow?

Moreover, if content is acquired *prior* to our work and used afterwards, what responsibility does the user of that content carry?  Should they ping robots.txt to get an updated version at the time of use?  Is that only applicable if there was no expression at the time that the content was originally acquired?  What if the site no longer has any record of that content and therefore the robots.txt doesn't obviously apply to the content?
